elements.content: “Converting” light energy to magnetization is the attribute of molecule-based compounds called photomagnets and is inaccessible for conventional magnetic solids. The design and synthesis of such compounds, however, is a formidable challenge, and only a few examples are known, all with rather low magnetic ordering temperatures well below the boiling point of liquid nitrogen. Herein, a cyanide-bridged coordination polymer, {[MnII(imidazole)]2[WIV(CN)8]} n , exhibiting the highest light-induced magnetic ordering temperature ever observed and a magnetic hysteresis loop up to 90 K is reported. The photomagnetic effect results from the blue light excitation (450 nm) of the constituent octacyanotungstate­(IV) moiety, which then couples magnetically with manganese­(II), resulting in light-induced ferrimagnetic ordering. The reported coordination framework shows also outstanding water sorption properties that are strongly correlated with the photomagnetic functionality. The photoswitching observed in the anhydrous state is completely quenched by the reversible capture of water, with the fully hydrated phase becoming practically non-photomagnetic.
elements.clean_text: "Converting" light energy to magnetization is the attribute of molecule-based compounds called photomagnets and is inaccessible for conventional magnetic solids. The design and synthesis of such compounds, however, is a formidable challenge, and only a few examples are known, all with rather low magnetic ordering temperatures well below the boiling point of liquid nitrogen. Herein, a cyanide-bridged coordination polymer, {[MnII(imidazole)]2[WIV(CN)8]} n , exhibiting the highest light-induced magnetic ordering temperature ever observed and a magnetic hysteresis loop up to 90 K is reported. The photomagnetic effect results from the blue light excitation (450 nm) of the constituent octacyanotungstate(IV) moiety, which then couples magnetically with manganese(II), resulting in light-induced ferrimagnetic ordering. The reported coordination framework shows also outstanding water sorption properties that are strongly correlated with the photomagnetic functionality. The photoswitching observed in the anhydrous state is completely quenched by the reversible capture of water, with the fully hydrated phase becoming practically non-photomagnetic.

elements.content: Modern chemistry seeks new multifunctional materials showing complex physicochemical properties. In the same vein, molecular magnetism focuses on the construction of magnetic solids by design using molecules as building units. The target compounds are expected to show nontrivial magnetic properties strongly coupled with other functionalities such as photoactivity or porosity. Due to the basically unlimited number of combinations, it developed into a much broader and fascinating field of multifunctional molecular materials with magnetism being the main theme.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Modern chemistry seeks new multifunctional materials showing complex physicochemical properties. In the same vein, molecular magnetism focuses on the construction of magnetic solids by design using molecules as building units. The target compounds are expected to show nontrivial magnetic properties strongly coupled with other functionalities such as photoactivity or porosity. Due to the basically unlimited number of combinations, it developed into a much broader and fascinating field of multifunctional molecular materials with magnetism being the main theme.

elements.content: Molecular magnets that are responsive to visible lightphotomagnetsconstitute a special class of multifunctional magnetic materials where magnetization is controlled by photons. However, the preparation of building blocks showing inherent photomagnetic functionality is extremely challenging. Photomagnetism is mainly studied in CN-bridged compounds with the CoII–FeIII charge transfer pairs, FeII spin-crossover complexes showing light induced excited spin state trapping (LIESST), and CoII-dioxolene pairs. 4d and 5d metal complexes are under-represented as LIESST candidates. Only recently were octacyanomolybdate­(IV) and octacyanotungstate­(IV) demonstrated to show intrinsic LIESST-like behavior. In the case of CN-bridged MnII–[WIV(CN)8] chains, an enormous increase of the magnetization upon 436 nm irradiation was observed, yet the photoinduced long-range magnetic ordering or the magnetic hysteresis was never detected when the photomagnetic effect was based solely on the octacyanotungstate­(IV). Herein, we present a three-dimensional (3-D) coordination polymer, {[MnII(imidazole)]2[WIV(CN)8]} n (1), showing light-induced long-range magnetic ordering above the boiling point of liquid nitrogen (LN2) and a reversible hysteretic water capture at room temperature that controls the photomagnetic functionality. The light-induced magnetic ordering temperature of 93 K, magnetic hysteresis loop at 90 K, and their control by water sorption are demonstrated for the first time.
elements.clean_text: Molecular magnets that are responsive to visible lightphotomagnetsconstitute a special class of multifunctional magnetic materials where magnetization is controlled by photons. However, the preparation of building blocks showing inherent photomagnetic functionality is extremely challenging. Photomagnetism is mainly studied in CN-bridged compounds with the CoII-FeIII  charge transfer pairs, FeII spin-crossover complexes showing light induced excited spin state trapping (LIESST), and CoII-dioxolene pairs. 4d and 5d metal complexes are under-represented as LIESST candidates. Only recently were octacyanomolybdate(IV) and octacyanotungstate(IV) demonstrated to show intrinsic LIESST-like behavior. In the case of CN-bridged MnII-[WIV(CN)8] chains, an enormous increase of the magnetization upon 436 nm irradiation was observed, yet the photoinduced long-range magnetic ordering or the magnetic hysteresis was never detected when the photomagnetic effect was based solely on the octacyanotungstate(IV). Herein, we present a three-dimensional (3-D) coordination polymer, {[MnII(imidazole)]2[WIV(CN)8]} n  (1), showing light-induced long-range magnetic ordering above the boiling point of liquid nitrogen (LN2) and a reversible hysteretic water capture at room temperature that controls the photomagnetic functionality. The light-induced magnetic ordering temperature of 93 K, magnetic hysteresis loop at 90 K, and their control by water sorption are demonstrated for the first time.

elements.content: 1 was obtained by the vacuum dehydration of {[MnII(imidazole)­(H2O)2]2­[WIV(CN)8]·4H2O} n (1-8H2O), which was synthesized according to the modified procedure for MoIV and NbIV analogues. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies of 1-8H2O (monoclinic, P21/n) revealed its 3-D CN-bridged coordination skeleton of crossed-ladder topology. As depicted in a, each WIV forms six cyanide bridges toward six MnII centers, leaving two terminal cyanide ligands engaged in hydrogen bonds with crystallization water molecules and aqua ligands of the MnII ions (). The [WIV(CN)8] moiety attains intermediate geometry between the square antiprism and the dodecahedron (Continuous Shape Measure Analysis; ). As aforementioned, the vacuum dehydration of 1-8H2O (10–2 mbar, 24 h, RT) affords the water-free 1 (four crystallization and four coordination H2O molecules removed). 1 was studied by means of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) structural analysis ( for details; single crystals of 1-8H2O crumbled in the process). The original crossed-ladder topology of 1-8H2O changes into square grids cross-linked by coordination ladders in 1 (triclinic, P1̅; b), which is very similar to that reported for the Nb analogue. The complete removal of H2O results in the formation of an additional WIV–CN–MnII cyanide linkage and the change of the coordination number of MnII ions to five and four, respectively (c and d). The tetracoordinate MnII resembles a distorted pseudo-vacant trigonal bipyramid where the “vacant” site is capped by an imidazole ring with the shortest MnII–Cimidazole distance of 2.95 Å (). This distance is significantly longer than that observed previously in the π-bonded stool-like MnII-pyrrolide complex (2.4–2.6 Å), which is the only other example of such geometry. The pentacoordinate MnII center, on the other hand, adopts a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The appearance of the tetracoordinate MnII-imidazole structural motif is accompanied by the formation of π–π stacks of four adjacent imidazole rings (). Another structural change upon H2O removal is the formation of a H-bond between the imidazole molecule and the remaining terminal cyanide ligand of the octacyanotungstate­(IV) moiety. All dehydration-induced structural changes leave no empty space in the crystal structure of the anhydrous phase. Yet, the dehydration process is reversible. The original structure and properties of 1-8H2O are completely restored by conditioning 1 at 95% relative humidity (RH), which leads to 1reh, {[MnII(imidazole)­(H2O)2]2[WIV(CN)8]·4H2O} n . presents the experimental PXRD patterns for all three phases 1-8H2O, 1, and 1reh in two consecutive dehydration-rehydration cycles.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Studies

 1 was obtained by the vacuum dehydration of {[MnII(imidazole)(H2O)2]2[WIV(CN)8]⋅4H2O} n  (1-8H2O), which was synthesized according to the modified procedure for MoIV  and NbIV  analogues. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies of 1-8H2O (monoclinic, P21/n) revealed its 3-D CN-bridged coordination skeleton of crossed-ladder topology. As depicted in a, each WIV forms six cyanide bridges toward six MnII centers, leaving two terminal cyanide ligands engaged in hydrogen bonds with crystallization water molecules and aqua ligands of the MnII ions (). The [WIV(CN)8] moiety attains intermediate geometry between the square antiprism and the dodecahedron (Continuous Shape Measure Analysis; ). As aforementioned, the vacuum dehydration of 1-8H2O (10-2 mbar, 24 h, RT) affords the water-free 1 (four crystallization and four coordination H2O molecules removed). 1 was studied by means of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) structural analysis ( for details; single crystals of 1-8H2O crumbled in the process). The original crossed-ladder topology of 1-8H2O changes into square grids cross-linked by coordination ladders in 1 (triclinic, P1̅; b), which is very similar to that reported for the Nb analogue. The complete removal of H2O results in the formation of an additional WIV-CN-MnII cyanide linkage and the change of the coordination number of MnII ions to five and four, respectively (c and d). The tetracoordinate MnII resembles a distorted pseudo-vacant trigonal bipyramid where the "vacant" site is capped by an imidazole ring with the shortest MnII-Cimidazole distance of 2.95 Å (). This distance is significantly longer than that observed previously in the π-bonded stool-like MnII-pyrrolide complex (2.4-2.6 Å), which is the only other example of such geometry. The pentacoordinate MnII center, on the other hand, adopts a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry. The appearance of the tetracoordinate MnII-imidazole structural motif is accompanied by the formation of π-π stacks of four adjacent imidazole rings (). Another structural change upon H2O removal is the formation of a H-bond between the imidazole molecule and the remaining terminal cyanide ligand of the octacyanotungstate(IV) moiety. All dehydration-induced structural changes leave no empty space in the crystal structure of the anhydrous phase. Yet, the dehydration process is reversible. The original structure and properties of 1-8H2O are completely restored by conditioning 1 at 95% relative humidity (RH), which leads to 1reh, {[MnII(imidazole)(H2O)2]2[WIV(CN)8]⋅4H2O} n .  presents the experimental PXRD patterns for all three phases 1-8H2O, 1, and 1reh in two consecutive dehydration-rehydration cycles.

elements.content: Strucutral diagrams showing the CN-bridged skeletons (a and b) and molecular fragments where CN-bridge formation occurs (c and d) in the pristine 1-8H2O (a and c) and vacuum dehydrated 1 (b and d). Dehydration leads to the transformation of one set of ladder motifs into corrugated square grids as a consequence of the CN-bridge formation (pink arrow in a and c) and the coordination number and geometry change of the MnII ions (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H, white).
elements.clean_text: 1  Strucutral diagrams showing the CN-bridged skeletons (a and b) and molecular fragments where CN-bridge formation occurs (c and d) in the pristine 1-8H2O (a and c) and vacuum dehydrated 1 (b and d). Dehydration leads to the transformation of one set of ladder motifs into corrugated square grids as a consequence of the CN-bridge formation (pink arrow in a and c) and the coordination number and geometry change of the MnII ions (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H, white).

elements.content: Experimental PXRD patterns for the pristine 1-8H2O (black), vacuum dehydrated 1 (orange), and rehydrated 1reh (green) demonstrating the reversibility of the water-sorption-driven structural transformation. The dehydration–rehydration cycle was repeated twice.
elements.clean_text: 2  Experimental PXRD patterns for the pristine 1-8H2O (black), vacuum dehydrated 1 (orange), and rehydrated 1reh (green) demonstrating the reversibility of the water-sorption-driven structural transformation. The dehydration-rehydration cycle was repeated twice.

elements.content: The dehydration–rehydration cycles can be performed repeatedly with the full retention of the chemical identity of the compound (IR spectra in ). Dynamic vapor sorption studies at 298 K show that the complete rehydration of 1 is achieved within 10 min at 95% RH (), with 22.6% relative mass increase perfectly matching the expected 22.57% corresponding to the absorption of eight water molecules per formula unit. 1 exhibits very good water sorption properties () of 0.19 g g–1 at P/P 0 = 0.3 as compared to typical water-harvesting systems under identical conditions: 0.30 g g–1 for MOF-801, 0.048 g g–1 for MCM-41, 0.10 g g–1 for UiO-66, 0.22 g g–1 for CAU-10, 0.44 g g–1 for MOF-841, 0.9 g g–1 for Co2Cl2BTDD, and 0.30 g g–1 for zeolite 13X (used for water adsorption chillers). Release of the adsorbed water occurs below 20% RH, with water content at P/P 0 = 0.1 equal to 0.060 g g–1. Note that other water sorption materials (i.e., molecular sieves or silica gels) might also be efficient at the investigated water pressure (P/P 0 = 0.3) but require higher regeneration temperature than MOFs or the reported compound. These properties make {[MnII(imidazole)]2­[WIV(CN)8]} n a very stable and convenient material for possible water-harvesting applications at room temperature and very low humidity levels. Further studies in this vein are in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Dynamic Vapor Sorption Studies

The dehydration-rehydration cycles can be performed repeatedly with the full retention of the chemical identity of the compound (IR spectra in ). Dynamic vapor sorption studies at 298 K show that the complete rehydration of 1 is achieved within 10 min at 95% RH (), with 22.6% relative mass increase perfectly matching the expected 22.57% corresponding to the absorption of eight water molecules per formula unit. 1 exhibits very good water sorption properties () of 0.19 g g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.3 as compared to typical water-harvesting systems under identical conditions: 0.30 g g-1 for MOF-801, 0.048 g g-1 for MCM-41, 0.10 g g-1 for UiO-66, 0.22 g g-1 for CAU-10, 0.44 g g-1 for MOF-841, 0.9 g g-1 for Co2Cl2BTDD, and 0.30 g g-1 for zeolite 13X (used for water adsorption chillers). Release of the adsorbed water occurs below 20% RH, with water content at P/P 0 = 0.1 equal to 0.060 g g-1. Note that other water sorption materials (i.e., molecular sieves or silica gels) might also be efficient at the investigated water pressure (P/P 0 = 0.3) but require higher regeneration temperature than MOFs or the reported compound. These properties make {[MnII(imidazole)]2[WIV(CN)8]} n  a very stable and convenient material for possible water-harvesting applications at room temperature and very low humidity levels. Further studies in this vein are in progress.

elements.content: Relative mass change of 1 (black line) during cycling in the 0–95% relative humidity conditions at 298 K (green line). Dashed line shows the predicted mass for the fully hydrated form 1-8H2O.
elements.clean_text: 3  Relative mass change of 1 (black line) during cycling in the 0-95% relative humidity conditions at 298 K (green line). Dashed line shows the predicted mass for the fully hydrated form 1-8H2O.

elements.content: The water-sorption-driven structural transformations of 1 have a significant impact on its magnetic properties. 1-8H2O and 1 show surprisingly different paramagnetic behavior. In the case of 1-8H2O, the χT value of 8.81 cm3·K·mol–1 at 300 K is close to 8.75 cm3·K·mol–1 expected for two octahedral MnII ions and remains roughly constant down to 30 K. Below this temperature it decreases and reaches 5.94 cm3·K·mol–1 at 1.8 K. The decrease is attributed to the weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the MnII centers (S Mn = 5/2) through MnII–NC–WIV–CN–MnII linkages (, green points). The paramagnetic behavior without any signs of magnetic anisotropy is also confirmed by the field dependence of the magnetization at 1.8 K (, green points) and the successful simultaneous fitting of both χT(T) and M(H) using the following Hamiltonian (PHI software): Ĥ = − 2 J Mn ‐ L ‐ Mn · S Mn · S Mn + μ B · g Mn · S Mn · B + μ B · g Mn · S Mn · B with the best fit parameters g Mn = 2.02(5) and J MnMn = −0.07(1) cm–1 (assuming local MnII···MnII antiferromagnetic interactions only). The anhydrous phase 1 shows basically the same χT value as 1-8H2O (8.79 cm3 K mol–1) at room temperature as compared to the expected 8.75 cm3 K mol–1 for two isotropic MnII ions. However, the χT(T) exhibits a much stronger decrease than 1-8H2O, starting already at 90 K and reaching 2.60 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K (, red points). The M(H) dependence recorded at T = 2.0 K attains the maximum value of 9.5 Nβ at 7 T, approaching the saturation of 10 Nβ expected for two isotropic MnII ions (, red points). Simultaneous fitting of both χT(T) and M(H) (PHI software) using reproduces well the former, but fails for the latter due to larger magnetic anisotropy that is not taken into account in the fitting (with the best fit parameters g Mn = 2.02(5) and J MnMn = −0.12(5) cm–1). All these observations suggest that 1 is paramagnetic but cannot be considered a magnetically isotropic system. Noteworthy, the magnetic properties of 1reh (after the first and the second rehydration cycle) are identical to those of the pristine compound 1-8H2O (Figures S7b and S8b, green points). There is also basically no difference between the first and the second dehydration cycle (Figures S7b and S8b, orange and red points), which confirms the “magnetic robustness” of 1-8H2O against repeated dehydration/rehydration.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

The water-sorption-driven structural transformations of 1 have a significant impact on its magnetic properties. 1-8H2O and 1 show surprisingly different paramagnetic behavior. In the case of 1-8H2O, the χT value of 8.81 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 300 K is close to 8.75 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 expected for two octahedral MnII ions and remains roughly constant down to 30 K. Below this temperature it decreases and reaches 5.94 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 1.8 K. The decrease is attributed to the weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the MnII centers (S Mn = 5/2) through MnII-NC-WIV-CN-MnII linkages (, green points). The paramagnetic behavior without any signs of magnetic anisotropy is also confirmed by the field dependence of the magnetization at 1.8 K (, green points) and the successful simultaneous fitting of both χT(T) and M(H) using the following Hamiltonian (PHI software):     Ĥ = - 2   J   Mn - L - Mn   ⋅   S   Mn   ⋅   S   Mn   +   μ   B   ⋅   g   Mn   ⋅   S   Mn   ⋅ B +   μ   B   ⋅   g   Mn   ⋅   S   Mn   ⋅ B   1 with the best fit parameters g Mn = 2.02(5) and J MnMn = -0.07(1) cm-1 (assuming local MnII⋅⋅⋅MnII antiferromagnetic interactions only). The anhydrous phase 1 shows basically the same χT value as 1-8H2O (8.79 cm3 K mol-1) at room temperature as compared to the expected 8.75 cm3 K mol-1 for two isotropic MnII ions. However, the χT(T) exhibits a much stronger decrease than 1-8H2O, starting already at 90 K and reaching 2.60 cm3 K mol-1 at 1.8 K (, red points). The M(H) dependence recorded at T = 2.0 K attains the maximum value of 9.5 Nβ at 7 T, approaching the saturation of 10 Nβ expected for two isotropic MnII ions (, red points). Simultaneous fitting of both χT(T) and M(H) (PHI software) using  reproduces well the former, but fails for the latter due to larger magnetic anisotropy that is not taken into account in the fitting (with the best fit parameters g Mn = 2.02(5) and J MnMn = -0.12(5) cm-1). All these observations suggest that 1 is paramagnetic but cannot be considered a magnetically isotropic system. Noteworthy, the magnetic properties of 1reh (after the first and the second rehydration cycle) are identical to those of the pristine compound 1-8H2O (Figures S7b and S8b, green points). There is also basically no difference between the first and the second dehydration cycle (Figures S7b and S8b, orange and red points), which confirms the "magnetic robustness" of 1-8H2O against repeated dehydration/rehydration.

elements.content: Solid state electronic spectra of 1-8H2O, 1, and 1reh are shown in . The lowest energy bands at 440 nm for 1-8H2O and 1reh (shoulder) and 450 nm for 1 correspond to the d–d transition of the octacyanotungstate­(IV) anion. This spectral region is free of any other absorption bands (i.e., imidazole or the [MnII(imidazole)]2+ moiety), making it a suitable target for photoirradiation. The light-induced magnetic experiments were performed using a blue laser diode (λ = 450 nm, optical power at the sample 6–10 mW/cm2). Surprisingly, 1-8H2O showed only an incremental magnetization change despite the constant 15 h irradiation at T = 10 K (, green points). Only a negligible change of the temperature dependence of the magnetization M(T) is observed (). 1, on the other hand, presents an unprecedented 15-fold increase of the χT at T = 10 K and H = 0.1 T (, orange points; see also , which presents the mechanism of the photomagnetic effect in 1). Moreover, the zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization curves measured at H = 20 Oe after irradiation bifurcate at 93 K (), suggesting that the irradiation leads to a long-range magnetic ordering at the record critical temperature T c = 93 K, well above the boiling point of liquid nitrogen. This observation is fully supported by the opening of the magnetic hysteresis loops with M r = 1.27 Nβ and H c = 3400 Oe at 2.0 K (a), M r = 0.07 Nβ and H c = 100 Oe at 77 K (b), and M r = 0.007 Nβ and H c = 25 Oe at 90 K (c), constituting the first system with the photoinduced magnetic hysteresis loop above the LN2 boiling point (). The broad maximum in the ZFC curve around 25 K () indicates that some parts of the sample (the inside) with weaker illumination might show spin glass behavior below 60 K. This, however, does not influence the long-range magnetic ordering of the surface layers, the T c of 93 K, or the hysteresis loops at 77 and 90 K.
elements.clean_text:
Photomagnetic Studies

Solid state electronic spectra of 1-8H2O, 1, and 1reh are shown in . The lowest energy bands at 440 nm for 1-8H2O and 1reh (shoulder) and 450 nm for 1 correspond to the d-d transition of the octacyanotungstate(IV) anion. This spectral region is free of any other absorption bands (i.e., imidazole or the [MnII(imidazole)]2+ moiety), making it a suitable target for photoirradiation. The light-induced magnetic experiments were performed using a blue laser diode (λ = 450 nm, optical power at the sample 6-10 mW/cm2). Surprisingly, 1-8H2O showed only an incremental magnetization change despite the constant 15 h irradiation at T = 10 K (, green points). Only a negligible change of the temperature dependence of the magnetization M(T) is observed (). 1, on the other hand, presents an unprecedented 15-fold increase of the χT at T = 10 K and H = 0.1 T (, orange points; see also , which presents the mechanism of the photomagnetic effect in 1). Moreover, the zero-field-cooled (ZFC) and field-cooled (FC) magnetization curves measured at H = 20 Oe after irradiation bifurcate at 93 K (), suggesting that the irradiation leads to a long-range magnetic ordering at the record critical temperature T c = 93 K, well above the boiling point of liquid nitrogen. This observation is fully supported by the opening of the magnetic hysteresis loops with M r = 1.27 Nβ and H c = 3400 Oe at 2.0 K (a), M r = 0.07 Nβ and H c = 100 Oe at 77 K (b), and M r = 0.007 Nβ and H c = 25 Oe at 90 K (c), constituting the first system with the photoinduced magnetic hysteresis loop above the LN2 boiling point (). The broad maximum in the ZFC curve around 25 K () indicates that some parts of the sample (the inside) with weaker illumination might show spin glass behavior below 60 K. This, however, does not influence the long-range magnetic ordering of the surface layers, the T c of 93 K, or the hysteresis loops at 77 and 90 K.

elements.content: χT vs time dependence recorded for 1-8H2O (green) and 1 (orange) at T = 10 K and H = 0.1 T during the irradiation experiment using a blue laser diode of λ = 450 nm. The initial decrease of the χT product after turning the light on is a heating effect of the laser light. The increase after switching the light off is the reverse effect due to the sample cooling.
elements.clean_text: 4  χT vs time dependence recorded for 1-8H2O (green) and 1 (orange) at T = 10 K and H = 0.1 T during the irradiation experiment using a blue laser diode of λ = 450 nm. The initial decrease of the χT product after turning the light on is a heating effect of the laser light. The increase after switching the light off is the reverse effect due to the sample cooling.

elements.content: M(T) at H = 0.002 T (3 K min–1 temperature ramp) for compound 1 during the photoirradiation experiment (a) and an illustration of the photoconversion of the paramagnetic state into the magnetically ordered metastable one (b). The paramagnetic state (before irradiation, black points) undergoes a photoinduced transformation into the magnetically ordered state upon 450 nm light irradiation (red points, FC; red circles, ZFC), which after heating to 300 K fully relaxes to the original paramagnetic ground state (blue points).
elements.clean_text: 5   M(T) at H = 0.002 T (3 K min-1 temperature ramp) for compound 1 during the photoirradiation experiment (a) and an illustration of the photoconversion of the paramagnetic state into the magnetically ordered metastable one (b). The paramagnetic state (before irradiation, black points) undergoes a photoinduced transformation into the magnetically ordered state upon 450 nm light irradiation (red points, FC; red circles, ZFC), which after heating to 300 K fully relaxes to the original paramagnetic ground state (blue points).

elements.content: M(H) magnetic hysteresis loops measured at 2.0 (a), 77 (b), and 90 K (c) after 450 nm light irradiation (red points) and after thermal relaxation at 300 K (blue points).
elements.clean_text: 6   M(H) magnetic hysteresis loops measured at 2.0 (a), 77 (b), and 90 K (c) after 450 nm light irradiation (red points) and after thermal relaxation at 300 K (blue points).

elements.content: The photomagnetic behavior of 1 is caused by the light-induced excited spin state trapping of the [WIV(CN)8]4– (WIV HS; S = 1) postulated before and the consecutive activation of the WIV HS–CN–MnII magnetic interaction pathways through the extensive cyanide skeleton of 1. The character of the magnetic interactions between the high-spin octacyanotungstate­(IV) and the manganese­(II) can be deduced from the analysis of the M(H) dependences recorded at T = 2.0 K. The M(H) curve after irradiation shows a significantly faster increase below 3 T compared to that before irradiation and reaches a significantly lower value at 7 T, only 8.3 Nβ vs 9.5 Nβ before irradiation (). Such a behavior can be explained assuming antiferromagnetic interactions between MnII (S = 5/2) and the photoinduced high-spin WIV HS (S = 1), resulting in the long-range ferrimagnetic ordering (see for a detailed explanation of this deduction). Similar antiferromagnetic interactions were observed and described for photomagnetic {[MnII(bpy)2]­[MnII(bpy)­(H2O)2]­[WIV(CN)8]·5H2O} n chains, although the long-range ordered state was not observed in that case.
elements.clean_text: The photomagnetic behavior of 1 is caused by the light-induced excited spin state trapping of the [WIV(CN)8]4- (WIV HS; S = 1) postulated before and the consecutive activation of the WIV HS-CN-MnII magnetic interaction pathways through the extensive cyanide skeleton of 1. The character of the magnetic interactions between the high-spin octacyanotungstate(IV) and the manganese(II) can be deduced from the analysis of the M(H) dependences recorded at T = 2.0 K. The M(H) curve after irradiation shows a significantly faster increase below 3 T compared to that before irradiation and reaches a significantly lower value at 7 T, only 8.3 Nβ vs 9.5 Nβ before irradiation (). Such a behavior can be explained assuming antiferromagnetic interactions between MnII (S = 5/2) and the photoinduced high-spin WIV HS (S = 1), resulting in the long-range ferrimagnetic ordering (see  for a detailed explanation of this deduction). Similar antiferromagnetic interactions were observed and described for photomagnetic {[MnII(bpy)2][MnII(bpy)(H2O)2][WIV(CN)8]⋅5H2O} n  chains, although the long-range ordered state was not observed in that case.

elements.content: The light-induced effect can be reversed by heating 1 to 300 K (compare the M(T) dependences recorded before irradiation and after thermal relaxation shown in ). presents χT(T) curves at 0.1 T measured before and after irradiation in the heating mode, which coincide around 200 K, constituting the relaxation temperature for this system. Above 200 K the photoexcited WIV HS ions relax to the nonmagnetic ground state (initial state). The slight differences in the M(H) curves before irradiation and after thermal relaxation (black and blue points in ) indicate a minimal damage of the sample. The slight decomposition is also visible in the IR spectra discussed in the . The irreversibility might be caused by a photoinduced dissociation of the W–CN bond. A mechanism of the photomagnetic effect based on the ligand photodissociation was postulated for the CuII–[MoIV(CN)8] molecules. The possible photoinduced metastable state [WIV(CN)7·CN] is supported by the recent report of the heptacyanotungstate­(IV) complex anion, which is paramagnetic (S = 1). The IR spectra recorded during the sample irradiation at 90 K present limited evidence for the aforementioned structural reorganization as the key for understanding the photomagnetism in 1 (). Overall, the stunning photomagnetic behavior of 1 might be related to the improved flexibility of the CN-bridged framework after H2O removal, which enables the coordination sphere reorganization including the photodissociation of the nonbridging cyanide ligand.
elements.clean_text: The light-induced effect can be reversed by heating 1 to 300 K (compare the M(T) dependences recorded before irradiation and after thermal relaxation shown in ).  presents χT(T) curves at 0.1 T measured before and after irradiation in the heating mode, which coincide around 200 K, constituting the relaxation temperature for this system. Above 200 K the photoexcited WIV HS ions relax to the nonmagnetic ground state (initial state). The slight differences in the M(H) curves before irradiation and after thermal relaxation (black and blue points in ) indicate a minimal damage of the sample. The slight decomposition is also visible in the IR spectra discussed in the . The irreversibility might be caused by a photoinduced dissociation of the W-CN bond. A mechanism of the photomagnetic effect based on the ligand photodissociation was postulated for the CuII-[MoIV(CN)8] molecules. The possible photoinduced metastable state [WIV(CN)7⋅CN] is supported by the recent report of the heptacyanotungstate(IV) complex anion, which is paramagnetic (S = 1). The IR spectra recorded during the sample irradiation at 90 K present limited evidence for the aforementioned structural reorganization as the key for understanding the photomagnetism in 1 (). Overall, the stunning photomagnetic behavior of 1 might be related to the improved flexibility of the CN-bridged framework after H2O removal, which enables the coordination sphere reorganization including the photodissociation of the nonbridging cyanide ligand.

elements.content: Our continuous study in the field of photomagnetic compounds has led to the unprecedented observation of a record high photoinduced magnetic ordering temperature of 93 K and a photoinduced magnetic hysteresis loop at 90 K in a [WIV(CN)8]-based 3-D coordination framework, {[MnII(imidazole)]2­[WIV(CN)8]} n , 1. This unique photomagnetic behavior, which can be reversibly switched “on” and “off” (ex situ) by the dehydration–rehydration process, clearly demonstrates that the application of multistable photomagnetic solids for the construction of novel photomagnetic devices is becoming feasible. Further efforts toward the construction of [WIV(CN)8]-based multifunctional photoswitchable magnets demonstrating even higher photoinduced magnetic ordering temperatures and better memory effects are in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Our continuous study in the field of photomagnetic compounds has led to the unprecedented observation of a record high photoinduced magnetic ordering temperature of 93 K and a photoinduced magnetic hysteresis loop at 90 K in a [WIV(CN)8]-based 3-D coordination framework, {[MnII(imidazole)]2[WIV(CN)8]} n , 1. This unique photomagnetic behavior, which can be reversibly switched "on" and "off" (ex situ) by the dehydration-rehydration process, clearly demonstrates that the application of multistable photomagnetic solids for the construction of novel photomagnetic devices is becoming feasible. Further efforts toward the construction of [WIV(CN)8]-based multifunctional photoswitchable magnets demonstrating even higher photoinduced magnetic ordering temperatures and better memory effects are in progress.

elements.content: All reagents were used as supplied from commercial sources (Sigma-Aldrich, Alfa Aesar). Potassium octacyanotungstate­(IV) was synthesized according to a known literature method. Samples for powder X-ray diffraction, IR, and photomagnetic studies were prepared inside an argon-filled glovebox (H2O < 0.5 ppm; Inert Technology).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All reagents were used as supplied from commercial sources (Sigma-Aldrich, Alfa Aesar). Potassium octacyanotungstate(IV) was synthesized according to a known literature method. Samples for powder X-ray diffraction, IR, and photomagnetic studies were prepared inside an argon-filled glovebox (H2O < 0.5 ppm; Inert Technology).

elements.content: 1-8H2O was obtained by mixing the water solution of 0.5 mmol (100 mg) of MnCl2·4H2O and 1.0 mmol (68 mg) of imidazole in 10 mL of water with the water solution of 0.1 mmol (56 mg) of potassium octacyanotungstate­(IV) dihydrate in 10 mL of water. After 24 h yellow column crystals were collected by decantation and dried shortly in air (typical yield: 30 mg, ca. 40%). The purity was confirmed by elemental analysis. Anal. Calcd for C14H24Mn2N12O8W: C 21.48, H 3.09, N 21.50; found: C 21.68, H 2.76, N 21.47.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

{[MnII(imidazole)(H2O)2]2[WIV(CN)8]⋅4H2O} n  (1-8H2O)

 1-8H2O was obtained by mixing the water solution of 0.5 mmol (100 mg) of MnCl2⋅4H2O and 1.0 mmol (68 mg) of imidazole in 10 mL of water with the water solution of 0.1 mmol (56 mg) of potassium octacyanotungstate(IV) dihydrate in 10 mL of water. After 24 h yellow column crystals were collected by decantation and dried shortly in air (typical yield: 30 mg, ca. 40%). The purity was confirmed by elemental analysis. Anal. Calcd for C14H24Mn2N12O8W: C 21.48, H 3.09, N 21.50; found: C 21.68, H 2.76, N 21.47.

elements.content:
1 was obtained by drying 1-8H2O over P4O10 for 24 h under vacuum (10–2 mbar) at room temperature. Anal. Calcd for C14H8Mn2N12W: C 26.33, H 1.26, N 26.35; found: C 25.71, H 1.36, N 26.44.

Physical Characterization

Elemental analysis was performed using an ELEMENTAR Vario Micro Cube CHNS analyzer. Solid state UV–vis spectra were recorded using a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 UV/vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integration sphere. For this measurement the sample suspended in paraffin oil was spread as a thin film between two fused quartz plates. IR spectra were recorded using a Nicolet iN10 MX FT-IR microscope in the transmission mode and a Linkam THMS350 V temperature-controlled stage. In the case of sorption reversibility IR measurements (), 1-8H2O was dehydrated by heating to 80 °C in a dry nitrogen atmosphere, while rehydration was performed by purging the sample chamber at room temperature with air at 95–100% RH.
elements.clean_text:
{[MnII(imidazole)]2[WIV(CN)8]}n (1)

 1 was obtained by drying 1-8H2O over P4O10 for 24 h under vacuum (10-2 mbar) at room temperature. Anal. Calcd for C14H8Mn2N12W: C 26.33, H 1.26, N 26.35; found: C 25.71, H 1.36, N 26.44.

Physical Characterization

Elemental analysis was performed using an ELEMENTAR Vario Micro Cube CHNS analyzer. Solid state UV-vis spectra were recorded using a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 UV/vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integration sphere. For this measurement the sample suspended in paraffin oil was spread as a thin film between two fused quartz plates. IR spectra were recorded using a Nicolet iN10 MX FT-IR microscope in the transmission mode and a Linkam THMS350 V temperature-controlled stage. In the case of sorption reversibility IR measurements (), 1-8H2O was dehydrated by heating to 80 °C in a dry nitrogen atmosphere, while rehydration was performed by purging the sample chamber at room temperature with air at 95-100% RH.

elements.content: The water adsorption isotherm was measured by a dynamic vapor sorption method using an SMS DVS Resolution apparatus in the 0–95% RH range at 298 K. The dehydration–rehydration cycles were performed at 298 K for a sample held in 0% or 95% RH until a constant mass was reached.
elements.clean_text:
Water Sorption Measurements

The water adsorption isotherm was measured by a dynamic vapor sorption method using an SMS DVS Resolution apparatus in the 0-95% RH range at 298 K. The dehydration-rehydration cycles were performed at 298 K for a sample held in 0% or 95% RH until a constant mass was reached.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS-3 Evercool magnetometer in magnetic fields up to 7 T. Samples for photomagnetic studies were ground to a fine powder and spread onto a colorless adhesive tape in the form of a thin 0.05 mm layer (ca. 0.2 mg, 0.2 cm2). In order to prevent 1-8H2O from dehydrating in the magnetometer chamber, it was initially cooled to 250 K and only then vacuum pumped. Irradiation was performed using a 450 nm laser diode (Thorlabs L450P1600MM). The power of the light was measured at the sample using Thorlabs optical power and energy meter PM100D. The experimental data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the sample and the sample holder. ZFC-FC measurements have been performed with a 3 K·min–1 heating rate. χT(T) was recorded with a 2 K·min–1 heating rate.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic and Photomagnetic Measurements

Magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS-3 Evercool magnetometer in magnetic fields up to 7 T. Samples for photomagnetic studies were ground to a fine powder and spread onto a colorless adhesive tape in the form of a thin 0.05 mm layer (ca. 0.2 mg, 0.2 cm2). In order to prevent 1-8H2O from dehydrating in the magnetometer chamber, it was initially cooled to 250 K and only then vacuum pumped. Irradiation was performed using a 450 nm laser diode (Thorlabs L450P1600MM). The power of the light was measured at the sample using Thorlabs optical power and energy meter PM100D. The experimental data were corrected for the diamagnetism of the sample and the sample holder. ZFC-FC measurements have been performed with a 3 K⋅min-1 heating rate. χT(T) was recorded with a 2 K⋅min-1 heating rate.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were performed using the Bruker D8 Quest Eco Photon50 CMOS diffractometer at 120 K (Mo Kα radiation, graphite monochromator). Absorption correction, data reduction, and unit cell refinement were performed using the SADABS and SAINT programs included in the Apex3 suite. The structure was solved using direct methods and refined anisotropically using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. H atoms of the imidazole ligands were placed in the calculated positions and refined as riding on the parent atoms. H atoms of water molecules were located from a difference Fourier map and refined with their U iso fixed at 1.2U iso of the parent oxygen atoms. The O–H distances were fixed at 0.95 Å, and the H–O–H angles were restrained using the DANG command in SHELXL. Structural diagrams were prepared using Mercury CSD 3.9. CCDC 1814690 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1-8H2O. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction, Structure Solution, and Refinement

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were performed using the Bruker D8 Quest Eco Photon50 CMOS diffractometer at 120 K (Mo Kα radiation, graphite monochromator). Absorption correction, data reduction, and unit cell refinement were performed using the SADABS and SAINT programs included in the Apex3 suite. The structure was solved using direct methods and refined anisotropically using weighted full-matrix least-squares on F 2. H atoms of the imidazole ligands were placed in the calculated positions and refined as riding on the parent atoms. H atoms of water molecules were located from a difference Fourier map and refined with their U iso fixed at 1.2U iso of the parent oxygen atoms. The O-H distances were fixed at 0.95 Å, and the H-O-H angles were restrained using the DANG command in SHELXL. Structural diagrams were prepared using Mercury CSD 3.9. CCDC 1814690 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1-8H2O. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

elements.content: PANalytical X’Pert Pro diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.541 78 Å) was used to collect all X-ray powder diffraction data. The measurements were performed at room temperature in the 3–50° 2θ angle range. The crystal structure of 1 was determined based on the structural model of the {[MnII(imH)]2[NbIV(CN)8]} n analogue reported previously. The unit cell was found in a triclinic system with the following parameters: a = 9.9810(5) Å, b = 10.8463(5) Å, c = 9.8571(5) Å, α = 103.871(3)°, β = 103.223(3)°, γ = 95.421(4)o, V = 995.85(9) Å3 (space group P1̅) using the PROSZKI package. The parameters were obtained by refining the unit cell of {[MnII(imH)]2[NbIV(CN)8]} n . Direct implementation of the previous model for the structure refinement was impossible, and the solution had to be determined from the beginning. To solve the structure, positions of one [WIV(CN)8]4– and two [Mn­(imidazole)]2+ moieties were optimized based on the direct-space method implemented in the FOX software. Rietveld refinement of the model was carried out using JANA2000 software. The final agreement factors are R p = 0.0322 and R wp = 0.0412. Due to the large number of light atoms in the model, which led to the instability of the refinement, only rigid-body refinement of the above presented moieties was performed. This procedure generates noticeably larger errors in some bond lengths and angles as compared to the traditionally refined structures. However, the agreement between the observed and calculated patterns () suggests that the framework of the structure was obtained with acceptable precision. CCDC 1859185 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction, Structure Solution, and Refinement

PANalytical X'Pert Pro diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54178 Å) was used to collect all X-ray powder diffraction data. The measurements were performed at room temperature in the 3-50° 2θ angle range. The crystal structure of 1 was determined based on the structural model of the {[MnII(imH)]2[NbIV(CN)8]} n  analogue reported previously. The unit cell was found in a triclinic system with the following parameters: a = 9.9810(5) Å, b = 10.8463(5) Å, c = 9.8571(5) Å, α = 103.871(3)°, β = 103.223(3)°, γ = 95.421(4)o, V = 995.85(9) Å3 (space group P1̅) using the PROSZKI package. The parameters were obtained by refining the unit cell of {[MnII(imH)]2[NbIV(CN)8]} n . Direct implementation of the previous model for the structure refinement was impossible, and the solution had to be determined from the beginning. To solve the structure, positions of one [WIV(CN)8]4- and two [Mn(imidazole)]2+ moieties were optimized based on the direct-space method implemented in the FOX software. Rietveld refinement of the model was carried out using JANA2000 software. The final agreement factors are R p = 0.0322 and R wp = 0.0412. Due to the large number of light atoms in the model, which led to the instability of the refinement, only rigid-body refinement of the above presented moieties was performed. This procedure generates noticeably larger errors in some bond lengths and angles as compared to the traditionally refined structures. However, the agreement between the observed and calculated patterns () suggests that the framework of the structure was obtained with acceptable precision. CCDC 1859185 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for 1. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

cln_elements.content: Strucutral diagrams showing the CN-bridged skeletons (a and b) and molecular fragments where CN-bridge formation occurs (c and d) in the pristine 1-8H2O (a and c) and vacuum dehydrated 1 (b and d). Dehydration leads to the transformation of one set of ladder motifs into corrugated square grids as a consequence of the CN-bridge formation (pink arrow in a and c) and the coordination number and geometry change of the MnII ions (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H, white).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Strucutral diagrams showing the CN-bridged skeletons (a and b) and molecular fragments where CN-bridge formation occurs (c and d) in the pristine 1-8H2O (a and c) and vacuum dehydrated 1 (b and d). Dehydration leads to the transformation of one set of ladder motifs into corrugated square grids as a consequence of the CN-bridge formation (pink arrow in a and c) and the coordination number and geometry change of the MnII ions (C, gray; N, blue; O, red; H, white).

cln_elements.content: Experimental PXRD patterns for the pristine 1-8H2O (black), vacuum dehydrated 1 (orange), and rehydrated 1reh (green) demonstrating the reversibility of the water-sorption-driven structural transformation. The dehydration–rehydration cycle was repeated twice.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Experimental PXRD patterns for the pristine 1-8H2O (black), vacuum dehydrated 1 (orange), and rehydrated 1reh (green) demonstrating the reversibility of the water-sorption-driven structural transformation. The dehydration-rehydration cycle was repeated twice.

cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Relative mass change of 1 (black line) during cycling in the 0-95% relative humidity conditions at 298 K (green line). Dashed line shows the predicted mass for the fully hydrated form 1-8H2O.

cln_elements.content: χT vs time dependence recorded for 1-8H2O (green) and 1 (orange) at T = 10 K and H = 0.1 T during the irradiation experiment using a blue laser diode of λ = 450 nm. The initial decrease of the χT product after turning the light on is a heating effect of the laser light. The increase after switching the light off is the reverse effect due to the sample cooling.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  χT vs time dependence recorded for 1-8H2O (green) and 1 (orange) at T = 10 K and H = 0.1 T during the irradiation experiment using a blue laser diode of λ = 450 nm. The initial decrease of the χT product after turning the light on is a heating effect of the laser light. The increase after switching the light off is the reverse effect due to the sample cooling.

cln_elements.content: M(T) at H = 0.002 T (3 K min–1 temperature ramp) for compound 1 during the photoirradiation experiment (a) and an illustration of the photoconversion of the paramagnetic state into the magnetically ordered metastable one (b). The paramagnetic state (before irradiation, black points) undergoes a photoinduced transformation into the magnetically ordered state upon 450 nm light irradiation (red points, FC; red circles, ZFC), which after heating to 300 K fully relaxes to the original paramagnetic ground state (blue points).
cln_elements.clean_text: 5   M(T) at H = 0.002 T (3 K min-1 temperature ramp) for compound 1 during the photoirradiation experiment (a) and an illustration of the photoconversion of the paramagnetic state into the magnetically ordered metastable one (b). The paramagnetic state (before irradiation, black points) undergoes a photoinduced transformation into the magnetically ordered state upon 450 nm light irradiation (red points, FC; red circles, ZFC), which after heating to 300 K fully relaxes to the original paramagnetic ground state (blue points).

cln_elements.content: M(H) magnetic hysteresis loops measured at 2.0 (a), 77 (b), and 90 K (c) after 450 nm light irradiation (red points) and after thermal relaxation at 300 K (blue points).

metadata.title:
A Photomagnetic
Sponge: High-Temperature Light-Induced
Ferrimagnet Controlled by Water Sorption
